summary: As a young boy, Tim (Aaron Murphy) witnesses the horrifying event of his father (Charles Mesure) being dragged away by the boogeyman. Despite the reassurances of his mother (Lucy Lawless) that the boogeyman is not real, he is never the same afterward. Years later, Tim (Barry Watson) manages to create a normal life for himself -- though he lives without closets and keeps his mattress on the floor. But when he learns of his mother's death, Tim must return home to face his childhood trauma.

reviews.content: It could have been a great psychological thriller but it's bogged down by mediocre writing and terrible CGI at the end

Wow. I'm so glad I didn't read the reviews before watching this movie, or I would not have even bothered to watch. I actually thought it was pretty good. I've seen all the clichés that horror movies have to offer - the shadowy figure in the background or running past in the foreground, and of course Boogeyman had those things. But there are some truly bizarre and unexpected things, (SPOILER)
such as Tim going into a wardrobe in a motel and then coming out of the haunted one in his bedroom in the old house, two seconds later. I liked the special effects too, even if it was a rollercoaster ride of CGI madness. The boogeyman didn't look too much the same all the time; it morphed and raced around enough to deceive and confuse the eye. I also liked Barry Watson as Tim. He gave a sensitive performance, reacting to his demon tormentor as any ordinary person would, vulnerable and terrified, yet forcing himself to be brave to try and protect his friends.

Not really scary at all. The director uses his camera in an attempt to fill in the holes left by a vacant narrative. There's not much story here other than a man tries to face his fears after an encounter with the boogeyman when he was young leaves him traumatized, he does this by revisiting his old home after his mother dies. It almost feels like the movie makers here realize that they haven't got much to work with so they try to create what tension, and scares, they can by having people walk around really slowly, and reaching for door knobs really slowly, until the ultimate final confrontation with a terrible looking CGI boogeyman. Watch once, and forget about it.

Boogeyman sets up the spooky atmosphere with a classic haunted-house setting and psychological tension, but if you're looking for a definitive study of our culture's paranoia with the self-titled enigma, there's plenty of superior alternatives.
